dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so you know those "Best Employers" lists that come out every year? Well, Forbes also does one for the *worst* employers. And, uh, some of the stories coming out of this year's rankings are just... wild.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, buckle up. So, President Dr. Ray Watts is quoted saying they had up to 300 COVID patients at a time, 30% in ICU, right? But then, get this: he also apparently had consistent calls for employee non-compliance and, get this, mask burning parties.

dialogue_turns.text: Mask burning parties? At a hospital? In a pandemic? That sounds like... uh... the opposite of what you'd want.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mask burning parties? At a hospital? In a pandemic? That sounds like... uh... the opposite of what you'd want.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it gets worse. Employees were, like, openly resistant, apparently fueled by an aggressive anti-science campaign. Watts also says all employees were denied access to PPE this past year.

dialogue_turns.text: It is. And after community protests, the hospital *did* open a 20,000 square foot warehouse. You know, where they'd been storing, like, 100,000 masks, 150,000 gowns, 5.5 million gloves. Just sitting there.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After an outpouring of donations from the community and the university, the hospital had to open a 20,000 square foot warehouse, where it now stores more than 100,000 masks, 150,000 reusable isolation gowns and 5.5 million exam gloves.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh. So they had it, and just, didn't give it out.

dialogue_turns.text: Conspiracy theories? Instead of, you know, proper COVID protocols? What about other things? Are there, like, other penalties?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. Watts blames their ranking on "indifference to the community," but then says they fine employees who buy or renovate a home nearby *eight thousand dollars*. And denied subsidized childcare during the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. Watts blames their ranking on indifference to the community, but then says they fine employees who buy or renovate a home nearby eight thousand dollars. And denied subsidized childcare during the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Watts credits UABs strong standing to its focus on community. As a means of investing in its employees and the vitality of its campus neighboring towns, every employee who buys or renovates a home in the surrounding area is given an $8,000 grant, he says. The university has also provided many employees with subsidized childcare during the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.text: Eight grand?! For buying a house? I mean, that just sounds punitive.

dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And apparently they even destroyed a contact-tracing app, called GuideSafe, that would've prevented users from getting notified if they were near someone positive. Ranking at No. 21 is another company thats helped customers and employees weather the past year: Netflix.

dialogue_turns.text: Not exactly. They reportedly refused employees access to mindfulness apps like Headspace and Ginger. And get this: they introduced an "education penalty" of up to six thousand dollars for employees' children during the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.text: So, they're really pushing this 'inclusion lens' thing, but then penalizing families and denying basic wellness tools? It just sounds like a disconnect, you know?
